articles.headline: G.O.P. Elects a New Chairman as Steele Drops Out
articles.snippet: Reince Priebus of Wisconsin survived seven rounds of balloting to succeed Michael Steele as party officials demanded new leadership.
articles.abstract: Reince Priebus of Wisconsin survived seven rounds of balloting to succeed Michael Steele as party officials demanded new leadership.
articles.lead_paragraph: OXON HILL, Md.  The Republican National Committee selected a new leader on Friday, with its choice, Reince Priebus of Wisconsin, surviving seven contentious rounds of balloting to overtake Michael Steele, the embattled chairman, as party officials demanded new leadership to fortify the party for the 2012 presidential race.

articles.headline: As Banks Raise Fees, You Have Options
articles.snippet: Don’t believe it when big banks say that new regulations are forcing them to impose checking account fees.
articles.abstract: Don’t believe it when big banks say that new regulations are forcing them to impose checking account fees.
articles.lead_paragraph: So now we know what the big banks’ New Year’s resolution was: Keep the profits flowing from basic checking accounts.

articles.headline: BP Forms Partnership to Explore in Russia
articles.snippet: The arrangement is expected to speed exploration of Russia’s Arctic continental shelf.
articles.abstract: The arrangement is expected to speed exploration of Russia’s Arctic continental shelf.
articles.lead_paragraph: The British oil giant BP agreed on Friday to a partnership with Rosneft, a Russian company, forming an alliance to explore the Russian Arctic.

articles.headline: Verizon Deal May Expose iPhone Flaws
articles.snippet: The problem with dropped calls on the iPhone may no longer be blamed on the network now that Apple has signed a deal with Verizon Wireless.
articles.abstract: The problem with dropped calls on the iPhone may no longer be blamed on the network now that Apple has signed a deal with Verizon Wireless.
articles.lead_paragraph: With this week’s announcement that Verizon Wireless is going to begin selling the iPhone  something its customers have been panting for ever since AT&T got that first, exclusive iPhone contract four years ago  it’s time for me to face the music. Nobody really cares that the iPhone is flawed. After this column, I’m going to stop caring too. I swear it.

articles.headline: Solar Panel Maker Moves Work to China
articles.snippet: Evergreen Solar, a leading maker of panels in the United States, is laying off 800 people and shifting production to China.
articles.abstract: Evergreen Solar, a leading maker of panels in the United States, is laying off 800 people and shifting production to China.
articles.lead_paragraph: BEIJING — Aided by at least $43 million in assistance from the government of Massachusetts and an innovative solar energy technology, Evergreen Solar emerged in the last three years as the third-largest maker of solar panels in the United States.

articles.headline: Tucson Shootings Add to Glock’s Notoriety
articles.snippet: Glock pistols, an Austrian invention now popular in the United States, have been newly scrutinized since a gunman killed six people in Tucson, Ariz.
articles.abstract: Glock pistols, an Austrian invention now popular in the United States, have been newly scrutinized since a gunman killed six people in Tucson, Ariz.
articles.lead_paragraph: New York City police officers carry Glock pistols, and rappers wax eloquent about them. Movie stars brandish Glocks, too.

articles.headline: From Bloody Scene to E.R., Lifesaving Choices in Tucson
articles.snippet: In a race to save lives, emergency workers and doctors made split-second decisions and families prayed for information.
articles.abstract: In a race to save lives, emergency workers and doctors made split-second decisions and families prayed for information.
articles.lead_paragraph: TUCSON — The moment Tony Compagno stepped off his fire engine, frantic people spattered with blood began running up to direct him to gunshot victims.
articles.byline: By Denise Grady and Jennifer Medina

articles.headline: U.S. Bills States $1.3 Billion in Interest Amid Tight Budgets
articles.snippet: States will have to pay hundreds of millions of dollars to the federal government on the billions they have borrowed to pay unemployment benefits.
articles.abstract: States will have to pay hundreds of millions of dollars to the federal government on the billions they have borrowed to pay unemployment benefits.
articles.lead_paragraph: As if states did not have enough on their plates getting their shaky finances in order, a new bill is coming due  from the federal government, which will charge them $1.3 billion in interest this fall on the billions they have borrowed from Washington to pay unemployment benefits during the downturn.
articles.byline: By Michael Cooper and Mary Williams Walsh

articles.headline: For Giffords, Tucson Roots Shaped Views
articles.snippet: In Tucson, it is clear how much Gabrielle Giffords’s political views have been shaped by her hometown.
articles.abstract: In Tucson, it is clear how much Gabrielle Giffords’s political views have been shaped by her hometown.
articles.lead_paragraph: TUCSON  Gabrielle Giffords grew up in an old house filled with old things at the edge of a city being remade by the new. While strip malls and subdivisions were rising everywhere else, her rambling brick residence was surrounded by 18 arid acres of cactuses and mesquite trees and decorated with Mexican art and Southwestern relics.
articles.byline: By Sheryl Gay Stolberg and William Yardley

articles.headline: In Tunisia, Clashes Continue as Power Shifts a Second Time
articles.snippet: The swift turnabout raised new questions about what kind of government might emerge from the chaos engulfing the country.
articles.abstract: The swift turnabout raised new questions about what kind of government might emerge from the chaos engulfing the country.
articles.lead_paragraph: TUNIS  Tanks, police officers and gangs of newly deputized young men wielding guns held the deserted streets of Tunis Saturday night after a day of sporadic rioting and gunfire. Power changed hands for the second time in 24 hours, and the swift turnabout raised new questions about what kind of government might emerge from the chaos engulfing Tunisia.

articles.headline: Looking Behind the Mug-Shot Grin
articles.snippet: Jared L. Loughner was described as a curious teenager and talented saxophonist. But when he was arrested after the Tucson shooting, a deputy detected no remorse.
articles.abstract: Jared L. Loughner was described as a curious teenager and talented saxophonist. But when he was arrested after the Tucson shooting, a deputy detected no remorse.
articles.lead_paragraph: This article was reported by Jo Becker, Serge F. Kovaleski, Michael Luo and Dan Barry and written by Mr. Barry.

articles.headline: Arbitration, Litigation, Aggravation
articles.snippet: The trust of Helen Cohen, who lost $700,000 on a real estate investment, was already in arbitration with its former broker when the company opened a court case as well.
articles.abstract: The trust of Helen Cohen, who lost $700,000 on a real estate investment, was already in arbitration with its former broker when the company opened a court case as well.
articles.lead_paragraph: WHEN investors file complaints against their brokers, the matters are almost always heard by an arbitration panel rather than by a judge or jury. Arbitration forums like those run by the Financial Industry Regulatory Authority typically adjudicate cases more quickly than the courts and less expensively, because costs associated with discovery and extensive legal filings are minimized if not eliminated.

articles.headline: Architects Find Their Dream Client, in China
articles.snippet: Smaller American architectural firms are receiving more commissions from China, and finding that Chinese clients are, in some ways, easier to work for.
articles.abstract: Smaller American architectural firms are receiving more commissions from China, and finding that Chinese clients are, in some ways, easier to work for.
articles.lead_paragraph: IT was an unusual commission, unlike anything that Stuart Silk, a Seattle architect, had been offered in his quarter-century of practice: design three high-end custom homes for clients he would never meet. Although there were some specifications for functions and dimensions  total square feet, for example, and the number of bedrooms and baths  there wasn’t a clue as to style or a construction budget.

articles.headline: Can Johnson & Johnson Get Its Act Together?
articles.snippet: The drug maker has a daunting task: to persuade consumers to buy its name-brand drugs, despite a string of recalls and quality concerns.
articles.abstract: The drug maker has a daunting task: to persuade consumers to buy its name-brand drugs, despite a string of recalls and quality concerns.
articles.lead_paragraph: LITTLE red flags jut out from the shelves at a CVS drugstore in suburban Boston, alerting shoppers to shortages of nearly a dozen Johnson & Johnson products. Among them are Motrin, Rolaids, children’s Tylenol liquid and adult Tylenol, Mylanta, Pepcid AC and even some Neutrogena skin care products.
articles.byline: By Natasha Singer and Reed Abelson

articles.headline: Israeli Test on Worm Called Crucial in Iran Nuclear Delay
articles.snippet: Operations at Israel’s Dimona complex are among the strongest clues that the Stuxnet computer worm was an American-Israeli project to sabotage the Iranian nuclear program.
articles.abstract: Operations at Israel’s Dimona complex are among the strongest clues that the Stuxnet computer worm was an American-Israeli project to sabotage the Iranian nuclear program.
articles.lead_paragraph: This article is by William J. Broad, John Markoff and David E. Sanger.
articles.byline: By William J. Broad, John Markoff and David E. Sanger

articles.headline: Tourists Mimic Polar Pioneers, Except With Planes and Blogs
articles.snippet: Tourists, adventurers and history buffs are lining up to visit the South Pole this year and next in honor of the 100th anniversaries of two polar expeditions.
articles.abstract: Tourists, adventurers and history buffs are lining up to visit the South Pole this year and next in honor of the 100th anniversaries of two polar expeditions.
articles.lead_paragraph: When the British explorer Robert Falcon Scott arrived at the South Pole only to find that he had been beaten there by Roald Amundsen and his team of Norwegians, he was despondent. “Great God! This is an awful place,” he lamented in his diary.

articles.headline: China Leader’s Limits Come Into Focus as U.S. Visit Nears
articles.snippet: President Hu Jintao is preparing to visit to defuse tensions with the United States, but he might not be able to keep relations from growing worse.
articles.abstract: President Hu Jintao is preparing to visit to defuse tensions with the United States, but he might not be able to keep relations from growing worse.
articles.lead_paragraph: BEIJING  With President Hu Jintao at the helm, China has become a $5 trillion industrial colossus, a growing military force, and, it sometimes appears, a model of authoritarian decisiveness, navigating out of the global financial crisis and sealing its position as the world’s fastest rising power.
articles.byline: By David E. Sanger and Michael Wines

articles.headline: Politically Confident, Iran Cuts Subsidies on Prices
articles.snippet: Iran has embarked on a sweeping program of cuts in its inefficient system of subsidies on fuel and other goods that has held back economic progress for years.
articles.abstract: Iran has embarked on a sweeping program of cuts in its inefficient system of subsidies on fuel and other goods that has held back economic progress for years.
articles.lead_paragraph: TEHRAN  After months of false starts, dire warnings and political wrangling, Iran has embarked on a sweeping program of cuts in its costly and inefficient system of subsidies on fuel and other essential goods that has put a strain on state finances and held back economic progress for years.

articles.headline: Europe’s Challenge: Fostering Growth Amid Austerity
articles.snippet: Weaker euro zone members are taking hard steps to stabilize their finances, but the strains on a currency that must serve both solvent and wavering economies are visible.
articles.abstract: Weaker euro zone members are taking hard steps to stabilize their finances, but the strains on a currency that must serve both solvent and wavering economies are visible.
articles.lead_paragraph: PARIS  Economic growth is an elixir for struggling economies, but in Europe it’s likely to come slowly to the countries that need it most.

articles.headline: Big Retailers Fill More Aisles With Groceries
articles.snippet: Stores known for selling clothes or aspirin, like Walgreens, CVS and Target, are expanding into the grocery business.
articles.abstract: Stores known for selling clothes or aspirin, like Walgreens, CVS and Target, are expanding into the grocery business.
articles.lead_paragraph: For dinner tonight, pick up some sushi and salad  at Walgreens. Or maybe some Target chicken.

articles.headline: Lawsuit Loans Add New Risk for the Injured
articles.snippet: Lending to plaintiffs is usually unregulated, leaving the industry free to ignore laws that protect borrowers.
articles.abstract: Lending to plaintiffs is usually unregulated, leaving the industry free to ignore laws that protect borrowers.
articles.lead_paragraph: Larry Long, debilitated by a stroke while using the pain medicine Vioxx, was facing eviction from his Georgia home in 2008. He could not wait for the impending settlement of a class-action lawsuit against the drug’s maker, so he borrowed $9,150 from Oasis Legal Finance, pledging to repay the Illinois company from his winnings.

articles.headline: For Magazines, a Bitter Pill in iPad
articles.snippet: The magazine industry is discovering that although Apple may offer new opportunities with its devices, it exacts a heavy toll.
articles.abstract: The magazine industry is discovering that although Apple may offer new opportunities with its devices, it exacts a heavy toll.
articles.lead_paragraph: The frustration that the country’s magazine and newspaper publishers feel toward Apple can sound a lot like a variation on the old relationship gripe, “can’t live with ’em, may get left behind without ’em.”

articles.headline: In New Military, Data Overload Can Be Deadly
articles.snippet: Raw information helps determine what targets to hit and what to avoid, but sometimes the data is overwhelming.
articles.abstract: Raw information helps determine what targets to hit and what to avoid, but sometimes the data is overwhelming.
articles.lead_paragraph: When military investigators looked into an attack by American helicopters last February that left 23 Afghan civilians dead, they found that the operator of a Predator drone had failed to pass along crucial information about the makeup of a gathering crowd of villagers.
articles.byline: By Thom Shanker and Matt Richtel

articles.headline: Piers Morgan Sets Himself as Larry King’s Opposite
articles.snippet: Piers Morgan, whose CNN talk show begins on Monday, is different from Larry King in many ways: obnoxious, obsessively prepared and a big self-promoter.
articles.abstract: Piers Morgan, whose CNN talk show begins on Monday, is different from Larry King in many ways: obnoxious, obsessively prepared and a big self-promoter.
articles.lead_paragraph: Fifteen minutes into the taping of his interview for “Piers Morgan Tonight,” the radio personality Howard Stern has already talked about his “King of All Media” bluster, his search for approval from his father, and whether he is, as Mr. Morgan put it, just a “domesticated little pussycat.”

articles.headline: Defying Conventional Wisdom to Sell Glasses Online
articles.snippet: Four business school friends are trying to persuade people to buy glasses online, with a mix of fashion, low prices, technology and customer service.
articles.abstract: Four business school friends are trying to persuade people to buy glasses online, with a mix of fashion, low prices, technology and customer service.
articles.lead_paragraph: Shopping skeptics said people would never buy certain things  shoes, diamond rings, cars  online because they needed to see the products in person. They were wrong. E-commerce companies have found success in all of those fields.

articles.headline: Publishing, Without Publishers
articles.snippet: Some brands are reaching out directly to consumers, cutting luxury publications out of the process.
articles.abstract: Some brands are reaching out directly to consumers, cutting luxury publications out of the process.
articles.lead_paragraph: In the not-so-distant past, a luxury brand like Richemont, the Swiss company that owns Piaget, Dunhill and Montblanc, would have killed for even the slightest attention from Jeremy Langmead, the editor of British Esquire.

articles.headline: Budget Worries Push Governors to Same Mind-Set
articles.snippet: The dismal fiscal situation in many states is forcing governors, despite their party affiliation, toward a consensus on what medicine is needed going forward.
articles.abstract: The dismal fiscal situation in many states is forcing governors, despite their party affiliation, toward a consensus on what medicine is needed going forward.
articles.lead_paragraph: CHICAGO  The dismal fiscal situation in many states is forcing governors, despite their party affiliation, toward a consensus on what medicine is needed going forward.

articles.headline: Tunisia Unrest Stirs Passions Across North African Region
articles.snippet: Six North Africans have set themselves on fire since the self-immolation that set off the uprising in Tunisia.
articles.abstract: Six North Africans have set themselves on fire since the self-immolation that set off the uprising in Tunisia.
articles.lead_paragraph: TUNIS  Passions unleashed by the revolution in Tunisia resonated throughout the region on Monday as an Egyptian and a Mauritanian became the latest of six North Africans to set themselves on fire in an imitation of the self-immolation that set off the uprising here a month ago.

articles.headline: Jobs Takes Sick Leave at Apple Again, Stirring Questions
articles.snippet: Steven P. Jobs, the chief executive of Apple is taking leave a year and a half after a liver transplant. Timothy D. Cook is to oversee day-to-day operations.
articles.abstract: Steven P. Jobs, the chief executive of Apple is taking leave a year and a half after a liver transplant. Timothy D. Cook is to oversee day-to-day operations.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO  Steven P. Jobs, the visionary co-founder and chief executive of Apple, is taking a medical leave of absence, a year and a half after his return following a liver transplant. The leave raises questions about both his long-term prognosis and the leadership of the world’s most valuable technology company.

articles.headline: Ex-Banker Gives Data on Taxes to WikiLeaks
articles.snippet: A former executive with Julius Baer said he had given details of more than 2,000 individuals and companies.
articles.abstract: A former executive with Julius Baer said he had given details of more than 2,000 individuals and companies.
articles.lead_paragraph: LONDON  A former senior Swiss bank executive said on Monday that he had given the WikiLeaks founder, Julian Assange, details of more than 2,000 prominent individuals and companies that he contends engaged in tax evasion and other possible criminal activity.
articles.byline: By Ravi Somaiya and Julia Werdigier
